Award.AwardTitle: Enhancement of Wet Lab Capabilities for Coral Reef Stress Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Central Caribbean Marine Institute (CCMI) is awarded a grant to build and equip a new Coral Reef Stress Wet Lab at its field station, the Little Cayman Research Centre (LCRC). The lab will be equipped with three primary wet lab work areas including a covered screened area, a climate controlled area, and a shaded screened area for experiments with a specific emphasis on climate change, ocean acidification, and fisheries management (lionfish and grouper). The new wet lab will enable LCRC to (1) enhance their capabilities and capacity for simultaneous research and education activities; (2) improve the quality, quantity, and accessibility of information produced and available at LCRC; and (3) enable them to better serve U.S. scientists and further develop collaborative partnerships with U.S. institutions and government.

Since 2006, LCRC has been providing oceanographic facilities that have enabled students and scientists to conduct field studies at a remote site where marine protection has been effective and where local human and development impacts are minimal. They have hosted over 90 visiting researchers and five major U.S. universities include a LCRC visit as a permanent part of their curriculum. CCMI also offers rich educational and conservation outreach activities for local K-12 Cayman Island schools which include underrepresented groups. Research at LCRC has led to major breakthroughs, including the discovery of new marine meiofauna species, an improved understanding of deep reefs, and new models for predicting coral bleaching and diseases.

The broader impacts of this infrastructure enhancement include producing new, high quality results on topics that are of the highest concern for society; providing a training ground for young scientists, who are the future of scientific discovery; attracting the best scientific minds and increasing the capacity of the station by establishing new partnerships and collaborations. Alongside existing long-term ecological and environmental data monitoring capabilities in partnership with NOAA- Coral Reef Early Warning System, the new facility will enhance the frontiers of science by collecting, publishing, and communicating results to the greater scientific community.

For further information about the Central Caribbean Marine Institute please visit: http://www.reefresearch.org/ccmi_website/home.htm

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Central Caribbean Marine Institute (CCMI) has completed a new Coral Reef Stress Wet Laboratory Pavilion at its field station, the Little Cayman Research Centre (LCRC). The pavilion is designed to enhance the capabilities and capacity for scientists and students to better understand the threats to coral reefs due to climate change and ocean acidification (OA). CCMI, with headquarters located in Princeton, NJ, now has facilities in the Caribbean which: (1) allow for simultaneous research and education activities; (2) improve the quality, quantity, and accessibility of information produced and available at LCRC; and (3) enable us to better serve U.S. scientists and further develop collaborative partnerships with U.S. institutions and government.

The LCRC wet lab pavilion increases the usability of the research station by accommodating a variety of new research and teaching activities. Covered and open deck areas provide ideal locations for aquaria to hold marine animals and plants and to process seawater and sediment. A climate-controlled area supports experiments and simulations that need varying light, temperature, and water chemistry treatments, all of which are important for understanding factors related to stress or resilience of reef ecosystems. A third area is shaded and screened for experiments that require natural light and temperatures. A seawater flow-through system throughout the pavilion provides the cleanest tropical water for fisheries management projects, including ongoing research on the abundant Nassau grouper and the invasive lionfish that populate Little Cayman’s coral reefs.

One important outcome of the NSF award is that several major U.S. university programs and international scientists will immediately utilize the lab to its fullest potential, demonstrating the need for such facilities. Our NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Little Cayman site award provides a diverse cross section of undergraduate students the opportunity to team up with leading scientists to study a common theme: coral reef biodiversity and resilience. The REU award helps CCMI realize its goal to support early career scientists by introducing them to a network of multidisciplinary researchers. Eight students, each representing his/her U.S. college or university, will be the first REU group to benefit from the new pavilion during an eight-week program which begins this June.

Another important outcome related to building the LCRC wet lab pavilion is the establishment of new international collaborative partnerships.  This summer, research teams from Japan, Germany, and the U.S. shall meet in Little Cayman to examine how climate change is being recorded in corals from as far back as the Pleistocene all the way to the present. The pavilion will serve as the lab in which they can process their geological samples before shipping them to their home institutes for state-of-the-art isotope analyses and other tests. This international effort will occur simultaneously with the REU program, providing the REU participants with a truly unique opportunity to witness paths along which their scientific endeavors may take them.

A broader impact of the new pavilion is that CCMI may continue its dedication to transferring science to society by offering rich educational and conservation activities related to our scientific findings. To date, CCMI has hosted over 100 visiting researchers, and six major U.S. universities include a LCRC visit as a permanent part of their curriculum. Each year, CCMI conducts outreach activities with hundreds of children and teachers, and thousands of visitors from the general public. Participants now have the opportunity to see science in action, offering rare insights into the lives of researchers and the topics they study. Such interactions are relevant both locally (through education and social outreach) and globally (through tourism and field station activity).

Since opening LCRC in 2006, CCMI has provided oceanographic facilities for students and scientists to conduct field studies at a remote site where marine protection has been effective and where local human-related impacts are minimal. Research at LCRC has led to major breakthroughs, including the discovery of new marine meiofauna and fish species, an improved understanding of deep reefs and coral reef sponges, identification of new fish camouflage, a model for predicting coral bleaching and diseases, the major touring exhibit “Creatures of Light: Hidden World of Coral Fluorescence”, and increasing curiosity by stakeholders and the general public in coral reef conservation. In 2013, a 14-year study indicated that the reefs in Little Cayman are on a positive trajectory, showing a remarkable recovery from the 1998 El Nino and subsequent bleaching events that have resulted in long-term damage elsewhere in the Caribbean. The completion of the new Coral Reef Stress Wet Laboratory Pavilion, with its capacity for conducting controlled experiments that simulate predicted climate change conditions, provides amazing opportunities to unlock the secrets of coral reef resiliency occurring in Little Cayman.
